text.p: - A number of Moscow commercial banks have been using their creditors' tax money to their own profit, delaying budget payments.
- People from the countries of the former East bloc go to Britain in search of a better life but, being illegal immigrants, find themselves stuck between a rock and a hard place.
- Armenian police in Yerevan have shaved the heads of all local prostitutes to make it easier to isolate them from foreigners coming for the World Chess Olympiad.
- President Yeltsin's chief-of-staff Anatoly Chubais is working hard to strengthen his administration to be able to also bring the government apparatus under his own control.
- Predictions of an imminent financial crisis make the government go out of its way to collect taxes.
- The row between Russia and Ukraine over the future of the Black Sea fleet base of Sevastopol is getting more and more acute -- though so far it is restricted to an unofficial level.
- Communist-era collective farms have gone into oblivion but new farmers still cannot make full use of the land which is supposed to be their own.
- A 33-year-old woman alcoholic walked free yesterday after a Moscow court found her not guilty of killing her eight-year-old, whom she starved to death in January 1996.
